text.0: @citizentvkenya Its earliest available official quarterly data shows #Kenya’s most recent recession was in 2002. https://t.co/DcBB5YmUA6
text.1: @citizentvkenya No, this is incorrect. While a recession may or may not have been recorded in 1992, the country’s national data agency @KNBStats did not have quarterly data for the years before 2000. https://t.co/DcBB5YmUA6
text.2:
:chart_increasing: #Kenya’s most-viewed TV station @citizentvkenya recently claimed on its website that the country last posted two consecutive quarters of negative economic growth nearly 30 years ago. 

But is this the case? https://t.co/DcBB5YmUA6
text.3: But experts say other factors also need to be considered, including the level of testing, the number of #COVID19 patients admitted to hospitals & those in critical care. https://t.co/3RTyvobKCo
text.4: Under @WHO guidelines, less than 5% of samples testing positive for at least two weeks is one indicator that could be used to decide if restrictions can be eased. https://t.co/3RTyvotm0Y
text.5: Kenyatta was more accurate with his numbers for September, when the rate ranged from 4% to 6%. https://t.co/3RTyvobKCo
text.6: The president was also off the mark with data for July, when the highest positivity rate was 13% and not 7%. https://t.co/3RTyvobKCo
text.7: In June, available official data showed that the highest seven-day positivity rate was 8% in the last week of the month, and not 13%. The rate only hit 13% in the last week of July. (Find out how we established this in our fact-check: https://t.co/B722wwYAd7)
text.8:
:Kenya: President Uhuru #Kenyatta recently warned that #Kenya was facing a “new wave” of #COVID19, claiming the country's “positivity rate had fallen from 13% in June of this year, to 7% in July, and to a low of 4% in September”.

But this is not all accurate. https://t.co/3RTyvotm0Y
text.9: @Chequeado @FullFact Fact-checking can impact politicians’ behaviour. But we need to better understand the circumstances that make this most effective and how to make it a durable effect. https://t.co/ORoY3Mtc26
text.10: @Chequeado @FullFact Interventions with young and adult participants, including long-term classroom training or just short trainings online, were all found to improve audiences’ ability to think more critically about the information they encounter. https://t.co/ORoY3Mtc26
text.11: @Chequeado @FullFact How we present fact-checks matters. Despite the emergence of a multitude of media formats, evidence suggests that articles which place the most important information at the top, avoid jargon & keep distraction to a minimum, are the most effective. https://t.co/ORoY3Mtc26
text.12: @Chequeado @FullFact There's mixed evidence on the role of fact-checks in updating beliefs for some types of misinformation. For claims linked to vaccine misinformation or conspiracies, the most effective approach is to prevent them from arising & spreading in the first place. https://t.co/ORoY3MbADw
text.13: @Chequeado @FullFact Fact-checks which identify what is wrong, explain why, and provide the right answer, are the most effective at updating beliefs. https://t.co/ORoY3Mtc26
text.14: @Chequeado @FullFact Some audiences will be more vulnerable to misinformation than others, but a certain bias towards believing things which are repeated, easy to process, and aligned with our worldviews make us all prone to believing misinformation to some extent. https://t.co/ORoY3Mtc26
text.15:
@Chequeado @FullFact We wanted to better understand some of the key questions we ask ourselves as #factcheckers, like who believes & shares misinformation, the impact of health misinformation & conspiracy beliefs. 

Here’s what we’ve learnt: https://t.co/ORoY3Mtc26
text.16: In 2019, @AfricaCheck, @Chequeado and @FullFact embarked on a year-long research project to get to the bottom of many key questions we ask ourselves as fact-checkers.
